description: The CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) certification designates IT professionals with advanced-level security skills and knowledge. CASP covers the technical knowledge and skills required to conceptualize, design, and engineer secure solutions across complex enterprise environments. CASP is approved by U.S. Dept. of Defense to meet IA technical and management certification requirements.
name: CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner
subtitle: CASP

episodes.description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and a brief amount of details about the exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for advanced security professionals that have knowledge of Security+, have a few years of experience in the field, and will go on to learn more advanced skills for those who are going to be managing and need to understand things like risk management and incident response.
episodes.title: CASP Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.130 --> 00:00:08.121
[SOUND]
Hello,

2
00:00:08.121 --> 00:00:12.570
in these videos we're gonna be covering
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner

3
00:00:12.570 --> 00:00:13.090
or CASP.

4
00:00:13.090 --> 00:00:16.516
And with me to go through all this
information and get us ready for

5
00:00:16.516 --> 00:00:19.000
the exam is none other than Mr.
Sean Oriyano.

6
00:00:19.000 --> 00:00:19.800
How you doing, Sean?

7
00:00:19.800 --> 00:00:20.710
>> I'm doing pretty good.

8
00:00:20.710 --> 00:00:21.380
How you doing?

9
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:22.420
>> I'm doing fantastic.

10
00:00:22.420 --> 00:00:26.360
So tell me Sean, we got the CompTIA
Advanced Security Practitioner.

11
00:00:27.360 --> 00:00:30.420
Who is the intended audience for
this exam?

12
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:34.500
>> Well the intended audience, if you
listen to CompTIA it's kind of vague on

13
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:38.070
it so that's something that
we do have to clear up.

14
00:00:38.070 --> 00:00:42.340
CompTIA kind of explains it as
advanced security professionals and

15
00:00:42.340 --> 00:00:47.760
okay, that sounds good, but
we kinda gotta fill in those gaps.

16
00:00:47.760 --> 00:00:51.810
It is correct to say it's
advanced security professionals,

17
00:00:51.810 --> 00:00:56.420
but it's still kinda fuzzy
to leave it like that.

18
00:00:56.420 --> 00:00:58.900
Yes, this is more advanced
than their other offerings.

19
00:00:58.900 --> 00:01:03.750
Security+, which would
definitely be more of a beginner

20
00:01:03.750 --> 00:01:06.630
level credentials to get into security.

21
00:01:06.630 --> 00:01:10.200
This just goes a little further and
a little broader than that.

22
00:01:10.200 --> 00:01:13.100
And so when you talk about advanced
security professionals, it's someone

23
00:01:13.100 --> 00:01:18.760
that's been in the field like three, four
years, I'd say, is probably pretty fair.

24
00:01:18.760 --> 00:01:23.180
Someone that has actively been working on
it since the earned their Security+ or

25
00:01:23.180 --> 00:01:25.120
have had that level of knowledge.

26
00:01:25.120 --> 00:01:27.230
It's those type of people.

27
00:01:27.230 --> 00:01:30.940
I would even say maybe job types
you're talking maybe managers.

28
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:33.900
That would be a good fit for this.

29
00:01:33.900 --> 00:01:37.240
It wouldn't be where the CISP is though,
that's an important thing.

30
00:01:37.240 --> 00:01:40.500
People do have that issue,
oh it's like the CISP.

31
00:01:40.500 --> 00:01:43.800
No it's not like the CISP,
it's different than that.

32
00:01:43.800 --> 00:01:48.574
If you put them in perspective,
you've got Security+, then the CASP,

33
00:01:48.574 --> 00:01:51.170
and then the CISP right up above that.

34
00:01:51.170 --> 00:01:55.530
And there's some crossover between
the CASP and the CISP but not a ton.

35
00:01:55.530 --> 00:01:57.172
>> Not a ton, okay, so
this is really good.

36
00:01:57.172 --> 00:02:00.730
Where Security+ or more for my people
that are implementing security or

37
00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:02.840
just getting started in security.

38
00:02:02.840 --> 00:02:06.530
This seems to be more geared to those
people that are making those decisions or

39
00:02:06.530 --> 00:02:10.950
designing those security plans for
the enterprise as a whole.

40
00:02:10.950 --> 00:02:17.660
>> Yeah, that would be a very good
place to put this into context.

41
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:21.760
Yeah, if you look at what the prior
offering was, that was just to get you

42
00:02:21.760 --> 00:02:25.020
acquainted with the technology and
some basics to get you moving around and

43
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:30.050
get you to be someone that is
functional as far as security goes.

44
00:02:30.050 --> 00:02:31.290
And have a basic understanding.

45
00:02:31.290 --> 00:02:33.450
It's not as simple as security awareness,
but

46
00:02:33.450 --> 00:02:37.400
you could say, it's security awareness for
IT professionals.

47
00:02:37.400 --> 00:02:41.780
It's going to technical stuff then where
the normal rank and file wouldn't get it.

48
00:02:41.780 --> 00:02:45.550
But it's someone that is
going to be managing.

49
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:50.032
Needs to understand risk management,
incident response, and

50
00:02:50.032 --> 00:02:55.760
the guys have the higher level look at how
networks and different technologies work.

51
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:59.040
So we're not getting into
necessarily legal stuff and

52
00:02:59.040 --> 00:03:02.550
everything at this point, in software
development stuff at this point.

53
00:03:02.550 --> 00:03:05.650
But we're starting to move further up
the scale to get a better understanding in

54
00:03:05.650 --> 00:03:08.570
this whole ecosystem and
all things that go around it.

55
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:09.200
>> Yeah, sure did.

56
00:03:09.200 --> 00:03:12.900
And I'm on their website now and I'll
throw the link for that in the show notes.

57
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:17.800
Just looking at the exam details,
they're saying that CAS-002 is out now,

58
00:03:17.800 --> 00:03:21.380
and 80 questions maximum.

59
00:03:21.380 --> 00:03:22.970
That can vary.

60
00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:26.280
Multiple choice and some performance
based questions are going to be on there.

61
00:03:26.280 --> 00:03:30.740
You have about 165 minutes for that exam,
so they give you a good amount of time.

62
00:03:30.740 --> 00:03:31.430
And pass or fail.

63
00:03:31.430 --> 00:03:33.060
There's no scaled score.

64
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:34.650
You either pass it or you don't,

65
00:03:34.650 --> 00:03:38.082
which always makes that last
click a little bit nervous.

66
00:03:38.082 --> 00:03:38.849
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

67
00:03:38.849 --> 00:03:41.778
that's why you're here because we wanna
get you the information you need so

68
00:03:41.778 --> 00:03:44.540
you don't have to be so nervous when
you click that finish on that exam.

69
00:03:44.540 --> 00:03:48.650
And prereq-wise, on their website, Sean,
they don't say there's any prereqs but

70
00:03:48.650 --> 00:03:53.100
they do recommend, as you said,
Maybe some Security+ at least,

71
00:03:53.100 --> 00:03:56.140
or a few years of experience in the field.

72
00:03:56.140 --> 00:03:57.830
>> Yeah, that would be fair.

73
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:02.270
Just jumping into this
exam you could do it.

74
00:04:02.270 --> 00:04:04.719
I mean it's entirely possible to do it.

75
00:04:05.900 --> 00:04:08.620
But one of the things
I've said even here is

76
00:04:08.620 --> 00:04:11.500
heck you can eat an ice cream
cone from the bottom up.

77
00:04:11.500 --> 00:04:13.375
>> [LAUGH]
>> But it's not really the best idea.

78
00:04:13.375 --> 00:04:15.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you could do this,

79
00:04:15.290 --> 00:04:20.080
you could jump right in with both feet and
do this, but

80
00:04:20.080 --> 00:04:23.600
it's probably better for
you to have something equivalent to or

81
00:04:23.600 --> 00:04:28.520
actually have the Security+ and have some
experience Before you jump into this

82
00:04:28.520 --> 00:04:34.055
because it is kind of a jarring
transition between the two.

83
00:04:34.055 --> 00:04:36.770
But if you've gone Security+ and
then you get up to this,

84
00:04:36.770 --> 00:04:40.500
you'll notice that all of a sudden you're
being exposed to a much broader and

85
00:04:40.500 --> 00:04:44.400
much more stuff than you saw
over on that side of the house.

86
00:04:44.400 --> 00:04:48.410
So you definitely wanna be working with us
and definitely wanna have some experience.

87
00:04:48.410 --> 00:04:53.120
Nothing says you have to have a Security+,
but It would be recommended that you

88
00:04:53.120 --> 00:04:59.150
possess at least that level of
knowledge and then some experience.

89
00:04:59.150 --> 00:05:04.010
Just even having the Security+ probably
isn't going to give you too much

90
00:05:04.010 --> 00:05:07.080
help on its own to even pass this.

91
00:05:07.080 --> 00:05:09.848
You kinda gotta have that
experience to understand and

92
00:05:09.848 --> 00:05:11.842
put everything in the proper context.

93
00:05:11.842 --> 00:05:15.955
>> All right, I hope everybody out there
is excited as we are to dive into our

94
00:05:15.955 --> 00:05:18.462
CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner.

95
00:05:18.462 --> 00:05:24.359
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Cryptography plays a huge part in securing data and networks. Viewers will hear about what cryptography is, why one uses it, how it fits into the context of CompTIA as an exam. Viewers will also hear a brief history of cryptography and the involved areas, which include confidentiality, integrity, non-repudiation, and authentication.
episodes.title: Cryptographic Goals

episodes.description: To be able to understand the process of cryptography, one should understand the key terminology used in the process. Viewers will hear definitions and explanations of terms used in the process of cryptography, so that the process in itself can be better understood.
episodes.title: Cryptographic Terms

episodes.description: Symmetric systems tend be very simplistic, which makes them efficient at processing bulk amounts of data. However, there's no way to do non-repudiation and tie an action back to a specific individual, and key distribution is also a challenge. Viewers will hear about the symmetric encryption process and some examples of how it works.
episodes.title: Symmetric Encryption

episodes.description: Asymmetric encryption is comparable to symmetric encryption in the sense that a key is used as a combination to an algorithm, but in asymmetric encryption different keys are used to encrypt and decrypt. Viewers will hear elaborated discussions of asymmetric encryption, further examples, and how it further compares with symmetric encryption.
episodes.title: Asymmetric Encryption

episodes.description: A hashing algorithm does not encrypt the original plain text, but generates a fixed length value and a unique set of characters for the inserted plain text. The hashing algorithm is not designed to be reversed and fits into the area of integrity, but also plays a role in non-repudiation. Viewers will hear discussions of what hashing is, different examples, and different uses for hashing.
episodes.title: Hashing

episodes.description: A Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is a method to manage keys and do validation. Viewers will hear about the different components of PKI like Certification Authority (CA) and Registration Authority (RA), and hear other topics like different types of digital certificates.
episodes.title: Public Key Infrastructure

episodes.description: In today's world, encryption is taking a bigger and bigger role in society as security issues become more prevalent. Cryptographic solutions are just different ways one can combine the things cryptography provides to get something that's going to address a certain problem. Cryptographic solutions are used to secure data at rest in forms of encryption, protect data in motion, and to make secure emails. Viewers will learn what cryptographic solutions look like in today's world and how it is actually put into place to design a secure network.
episodes.title: Cryptographic Solutions

episodes.description: Cryptographic attacks come from people trying to break cryptographic solutions. Viewers will hear about some of the different kinds of attacks one has to deal with like frequency analysis and brute force tactics to help people become more aware so they can be better prepared and defend networks against them.
episodes.title: Cryptographic Attacks

episodes.description: When one gets into the realm of advanced network design and advanced security, it is important to understand serious threats and what they look like. One would need to know what kind of risks they have, how to assess the risk, and then apply appropriate corrective measures to bring down that risk. Viewers will hear about ways one can design a network to keep that network secure and things one can bring into a modern network to give it another level of security.
episodes.title: Advanced Network Design

episodes.description: Remote access utilities like Telnet, allow one to log into various services remotely for command line access to transfer files, issue commands to a system, or etc. Viewers will hear information about remote access and different choices one has to make when designing secure solutions.
episodes.title: Remote Access

episodes.description: Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems are involved with anything that automates control over machinery and are involved with things like power plants, electrical grids, utilities, and manufacturing processes. Viewers will also hear about the vulnerabilities associated with SCADA and how it can be prone to attacks.
episodes.title: SCADA

episodes.description: TCP/IP is a multi-layered protocol suite that is mainly covered within the content of Network+. Viewers are expected to have a knowledge equivalent to what's on Network+, but will also hear an overview of the TCP/IP and OSI model to better fully understand how it works, so that one can secure it properly and understand the different involved layers.
episodes.title: TCP/IP

episodes.description: Secure facility solutions deal with physical security and different facilities require different levels of physical security, which securing a facility can actually be a important part in securing a network. Viewers will hear the importance of physical security, what it means, and how lacking in physical security can cause problems.
episodes.title: Secure Facility Solutions

episodes.description: When it comes to securing network infrastructure, it is important to have it set up properly. Routers are a big part in network design and with that comes with a lot of configuration and a lot of room for error. Viewers will hear discussions and information about routers and switches and see the toolset within the Kali Linux environment to help check and secure routers.
episodes.title: Secure Network Infrastructure

episodes.description: Securing network traffic is important in dealing with both data at rest and data in motion. Viewers will hear about different components in the security of a network, including IPsec and firewalls and see demonstrations of setting up IPsec policies.
episodes.title: Securing Network Traffic

episodes.description: Web service security is especially important when dealing with securing servers. Viewers will hear information on securing web servers and services running on those web servers, as well as see demonstrations from programs like Netcraft and ID Serve as a way to get basic information about a system.
episodes.title: Web Services Security

episodes.description: Shared computing can have many perceived benefits, but it can also be very problematic on the IT side of things. Viewers will hear discussions of the benefits and risks associated with cloud services and enterprise security.
episodes.title: Distributed & Shared Computing

episodes.description: When deciding to move over to cloud services, one should research different solutions to see which solution would be most fitting. Viewers will hear discussions on the various types of cloud solutions and what one needs to know to be aware of it when designing a secure network.
episodes.title: Cloud Computing

episodes.description: Virtualization lets one consolidate servers, isolate operating systems and applications, test development processes, and much more. Viewers will hear about the different facets of virtualization and other subtopics which include virtual LANs and enterprise storage.
episodes.title: Virtualization

episodes.description: When accessing different hosts, host security is an important factor to include. Viewers will hear about the different types of hosts, which include servers, clients, and cameras and will also hear how to discover them.
episodes.title: Intro to Host Security

episodes.description: A firewall is a device that blocks all ports except for designated traffic that a user wants to allow on their network. Viewers will hear about different types of firewalls, where they should be put within a network, and how to test them to make sure they are set up properly.
episodes.title: Firewalls and ACLs

episodes.description: Host hardening involves the installation of a given system and upgrading the security level to a point that is better and more appropriate for a particular situation. Viewers will hear about trusted operating systems and trusted computer bases (TCB) and the different sets of endpoint security like anti-malware, anti-spyware, and spam filters.
episodes.title: Host Hardening

episodes.description: Using tools to harden a system can better protect a network from being broken into. Viewers will see demonstrations of the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) and hear about other tools like Nessus and Nexpose that can also help one harden a system to better protect a network.
episodes.title: Host Hardening Part 2

episodes.description: Data exfiltration constitutes as data/information that leaves an organization that shouldn't leave or be taken. Viewers will hear about data exfiltration, the damage it can cause to an organization, and some measures that are put into place to prevent leaks in information.
episodes.title: Data Exfiltration

episodes.description: Application security is another big part in securing a network that has a lot of vulnerabilities to it. Generally, as functionality increases, ease of use and security decrease. Viewers will hear about the complexities associated with application security and all the sorts of things that need to be considered when securing applications.
episodes.title: Application Security

episodes.description: Hardening applications is also an advisable measure to help protect and secure a network against possible issues. Viewers will hear discussions about specific web based application issues one has to deal with like cross site scripting, click jacking, session hijacking, poor input validation, and the importance of securing them.
episodes.title: Specific Application Issues

episodes.description: Sandboxing is a way of isolating or controlling access to resources and limiting the access of applications and what they can do. Viewers will learn about sandboxing and see demonstrations of the Sandboxie application for better knowledge of how to safely test applications without putting ones system at risk.
episodes.title: Application Sandboxing

episodes.description: Application security framework is a way of creating software, testing it, and evaluating the step by step process before it becomes a full-fledged application. Viewers will hear discussions on application security frameworks, phases of the Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC), and other processes.
episodes.title: Application Security Framework

episodes.description: To avoid improperly storing data, one should classify their data, know what data is considered sensitive, and have good storage techniques. Viewers will be made aware of the risks of improperly storing data and will also hear about utilities like Burp Suite that view interactions between web browsers and web applications.
episodes.title: Improper Data Storage

episodes.description: When it comes to applications and security, one will need to know about the different kinds of issues they have in order to properly maintain them. Viewers will hear discussions about some of the issues associated with Java Script, HTML 5, and Adobe Flash as well as other issues like buffer overflow, memory leaks, and resource exhaustion.
episodes.title: Other Application Issues

episodes.description: Penetration testing plays a valuable role in determining what one's security stance actually is. Viewers will hear discussions about when it is necessary to perform a penetration test, some of the involved steps, and how to decide areas for assessment.
episodes.title: Penetration Testing

episodes.description: There are a lot of different risks that can harm the integrity of a collection of data, which include data corruption, data deletion, and data theft. Risk management involves identifying risks and then finding ways to mitigate those risks to prevent possible damage. Viewers will hear about the process of risk management and assessing risks in a business setting.
episodes.title: Intro to Risk Management

episodes.description: In the process of risk assessment, one should know what assets they are protecting from risk. Viewers will hear about the different steps involved in the risk assessment process including asset identification, information classification, risk assessment, risk analysis, implementing controls, and continuous monitoring.
episodes.title: Risk Assessment Process

episodes.description: Policy documents contain policies and procedures that do a number of things like help make a business work the way it's supposed to, keep the confidence of its customers, and protect employees and assets. Viewers will hear a broad overview about the ramifications of lacking certain policies, policy development, and how to know if an organization has done enough in policy implementation.
episodes.title: High Level Documentation

episodes.description: A policy is a statement of intent and is implemented with procedures and protocols which all fit together to form something that actually manages information and people. Viewers will hear about the general procedure in creating policies, business documents used to support security, and hear other discussed terms like programs, guidelines, and baselines.
episodes.title: Policies and Procedures

episodes.description: Documents can contain some sensitive information, so it is important to make sure that information doesn't get into the wrong hands of someone who shouldn't have access to it. Viewers will hear about what to do with hard copies of data and some issues with disposal of information.
episodes.title: Documents and Controls

episodes.description: Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is any information that could identify a particular individual either directly or indirectly. Viewers will hear discussions about PII that can lead to data breaches and penalties and also hear how to keep that information secure.
episodes.title: PII Controls

episodes.description: The ability to do auditing is a very important part of security, which includes verifying if security mechanisms are working properly and being handled correctly. Viewers will hear about auditing policies and requirements, who conducts them, and how often they occur.
episodes.title: Auditing Requirements & Frequency

episodes.description: An incident is an event that's not planned for outside of normal operations or something that disrupts those normal operations. Viewers will hear some examples of incident response frameworks in place, some steps involved, and the importance of having it in place before an incident occurs.
episodes.title: Incident Response Framework

episodes.description: Digital forensics can have a significant amount of importance when it comes to incident response protocols and overall functioning. Viewers will hear information about digital and traditional forensics, the importance of it, and some complexities usually involved with it.
episodes.title: Digital Forensics

episodes.description: Everyone in an organization has a part to play in security, and helping to inform users about some of the different areas in security can make a big difference. Viewers will hear more about how digital forensics fits in with incident response, the role it plays in security, and legal requirements involved with it.
episodes.title: Digital Forensics Part 2

episodes.description: Security is always advancing, so conducting research on Industry trends is a great way to gain information to become updated with the latest technology. Viewers will hear the importance of industry trends to security research and how staying up to date with the latest technology can be beneficial and help a user to be more aware of vulnerabilities.
episodes.title: Trends and Ongoing Research

episodes.description: Legal guidelines act as a set of best practices to follow that ensure certain levels of performance without being penalized. Viewers will hear about some issues with legal liabilities, best practices when it comes to standards, and hear terms like due care and due diligence explained.
episodes.title: Legal Guidelines

episodes.description: New systems in technology usually bring new threats along with it, so learning how to properly adapt to emerging technologies can also act as a security measure as well. Viewers will hear discussions on how new technology can impact a network and what sort of things can represent a threat like ransomeware and cryptoviruses.
episodes.title: Adapting to New Technologies

episodes.description: Social media at times can be an outlet where people accidentally/ intentionally compromise company information or sensitive data that can have a vast amount of negative implications. Viewers will hear some concerns with social media and the impact it can have to enterprise infrastructure.
episodes.title: Implications of New Media

episodes.description: It's important to stay on top of the latest and best information out there and Global Information Awareness is a way to do that. In response to collective security threats, an increasing number of groups and communities have been created to share information that will expose people to new viewpoints, new technologies, and new techniques other people are using to become better informed how to solve different security issues. Viewers will hear about ways to stay up to date with the latest security information and new certifications and training that could help people gain that knowledge.
episodes.title: Global IA Community

episodes.description: Bringing in contractors into an enterprise environment can have some potential difficulties when it comes to following company policies, procedures, rules, and regulations. Viewers will hear about the sorts of things entailed in hiring a contractor and the potential problems tied to it.
episodes.title: Working with Contractors

episodes.description: Cyber defense aids are new techniques and technologies designed to more closely analyze, pattern, and model threats, which can include deconstructing them so they can be better understood. Viewers will hear discussions on reverse engineering software and analyzing network traffic.
episodes.title: Cyber Defense Aids

episodes.description: After Action Reviews (AAR) help people to know what they should be changing when updating a document to improve a process. Viewers will hear about the benefits of AARs and some of the judgement calls involved in leading a process toward a better path of improvement.
episodes.title: Performing a Review

episodes.description: The integration of different disciplines can help to create security solutions in an enterprise environment. Viewers will hear about different disciplines, the importance of leadership and experience in the integration of different disciplines, and how governance fits in with solutions.
episodes.title: Integrating Disciplines

episodes.description: Effective managing can encourage communication and collaboration between people in an organization. Viewers will hear about management principles and changes within management, as well as the importance of effective communication.
episodes.title: Management Principles

episodes.description: When it comes to things like third party products that are put on top of trusted computer bases, some research will need to be done first to know some of the risks and issues associated with them. Viewers will hear discussions about ways to mitigate risks or challenges with third party products, find an acceptable level of risk, and to research the situation to find the third party solution that is most fitting.
episodes.title: Third Party Product Risks

episodes.description: Communication security control entails setting things in place to effectively secure different types of communication. Viewers will hear about unified communication solutions, vulnerabilities in those solutions, how planning ahead can solve a lot of problems, and some benefits and vulnerabilities associated with voice over IP security and remote access.
episodes.title: Communication Security Controls

episodes.description: Securing mobile devices is a great way to minimize the exposure of risks in an enterprise. Viewers will hear about different ways to manage mobile devices, challenges with them, and security concerns with the implementation of collaboration platforms.
episodes.title: Mobile Device Management

episodes.description: Advanced authentication builds off of already existing authentication techniques that confirm one’s identity to grant them into anything they should have access to. Viewers will hear discussions on active directory, single sign-on, and some of the main areas of advanced authentication.
episodes.title: Advanced Authentication

episodes.description: As technologies move through their lifecycle in an organization, one should stay aware of growing security issues and other concerning matters. Viewers will hear about integrating new technologies, emerging threats in security transitions, and securely disposing of systems.
episodes.title: Secure Lifecycle

episodes.description: Validating system designs is another way to check out a system to make sure it meets specific requirements. Viewers will hear about how one goes about validating system designs and about the change management process.
episodes.title: Validate System Design
